questions.question: According to HTML file naming conventions, which of the following is the correct way to name an HTML file?
options: My Page.html
my_page.html
MyPage!.html
my page.html
questions.explanation: HTML files should use lowercase letters, no spaces, and avoid special characters. Dashes and underscores are acceptable, so 'my_page.html' is correct.

questions.question: How does the browser interpret white space in HTML?
options: The browser preserves all white space exactly as written in the code.
The browser ignores white space, so multiple spaces and line breaks are collapsed.
The browser only ignores spaces but preserves line breaks.
The browser converts all white space to single spaces.
questions.explanation: The browser ignores white space in HTML, which means multiple spaces, tabs, and line breaks are collapsed. This is why formatting your code with indentation doesn't affect how the page displays.

questions.question: What is the recommended practice for making HTML code readable?
options: Write everything on a single line to save space.
Use indentation and line breaks to organize nested elements.
Use only tabs, never spaces.
Remove all comments to keep code clean.
questions.explanation: Using indentation and line breaks helps organize nested HTML elements, making the code much easier to read and maintain. This is a best practice for all HTML code.

questions.question: What is the correct syntax for HTML attributes?
options: src=my_image.jpg
src="my_image.jpg"
src: my_image.jpg
src -> my_image.jpg
questions.explanation: HTML attributes must be followed by an equals sign, and the values must be surrounded by quotation marks. The correct syntax is: attribute="value".

questions.question: What is the correct syntax for an HTML comment?
options: // This is a comment
/* This is a comment */
<!-- This is a comment -->
# This is a comment
questions.explanation: HTML comments use the syntax <!-- comment -->. Comments are ignored by the browser but are useful for documenting your code.

questions.question: Where should the link to a CSS stylesheet be placed in an HTML document?
options: Inside the <body> tag
Inside the <head> tag
At the end of the document
Anywhere in the document
questions.explanation: Links to CSS stylesheets should be placed inside the <head> tag of the HTML document. This ensures the styles are loaded before the page content is rendered.

questions.question: Where should all visible content (headers, images, paragraphs, etc.) be placed in an HTML document?
options: Inside the <head> tag
Inside the <body> tag
Outside both <head> and <body> tags
It doesn't matter where you put it
questions.explanation: All visible content, including headers, images, paragraphs, videos, and audio, must be placed inside the <body> tag. The <head> tag is for metadata, not visible content.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Browser Inspector?
options: To create new HTML files
To inspect HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code from within the browser, useful for debugging and exploring code
To automatically fix errors in your code
To convert HTML to other formats
questions.explanation: The Browser Inspector (also called Developer Tools) allows you to inspect HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code from within the browser. It's useful for finding bugs, experimenting with code, and exploring how websites are built.

questions.question: Consider this code: ```html ``` What is the purpose of the 'src' attribute?
options: It specifies the alternative text to display if the image fails to load
It specifies the path or URL to the image file that should be displayed
It sets the image size
It defines the image format
questions.explanation: The 'src' attribute specifies the source (path or URL) of the image file. In this case, it tells the browser to load and display 'dog.jpg'. The 'alt' attribute provides alternative text for accessibility.

questions.question: Consider this code: ```html Visit Example ``` What is the purpose of the 'href' attribute?
options: It styles the link text
It specifies the destination URL or path that the link should navigate to
It sets the link color
It makes the link open in a new window
questions.explanation: The 'href' attribute (hypertext reference) specifies the destination URL or path. When the link is clicked, the browser navigates to that location. In this example, clicking 'Visit Example' would take you to https://example.com.
